ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: -Deeper knowledge of Ottoman historiography -Presentation skills, from opening class discussions for specific readings -Our readings in Ottoman legal history and the kadi courts were especially helpful -I greatly appreciated how balanced the syllabus was in terms of chronological coverage (we covered a lot of ground in just 4 months)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Assigning two books per seminar is the only point of weakness in this course. With this workload I found that I could never cover as much ground with each book as I normally can in courses where one is assigned each week. This might be a matter of preference, but assigning one book per week allows for deeper close reading.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If they specialize in Ottoman and/or Middle Eastern History I would definitely recommend this course to another student. However, given the concentrated scope and volume of the readings, I would not do so if another graduate student were a non-specialist.
